column1: Bad River Band of the Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa Indians of the Bad River Reservation, Wisconsin,BadRiver,"Beloit College, Logan Museum of Anthropology",BeloitLoganMuseumOfAnthropology,Wisconsin,Ashland,Marina site (47As24),LMA 7302,2,9,"In 1975 human remains representing a minimum of one individual (""Burial 2"") were removed from the Marina site (47As24), La Pointe Township, Madeline Island, Ashland County, WI by crews from Beloit College directed by Robert J. column1: Bad River Band of the Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa Indians of the Bad River Reservation, Wisconsin,BadRiver,"Beloit College, Logan Museum of Anthropology",BeloitLoganMuseumOfAnthropology,Wisconsin,Langlade,Pine Point site(47Lg21),LMA 21493W,1,0,"In 1968 or earlier, human remains representing a single individual were recovered during installation of a septic tank with a backhoe at the Pine Point Resort, Pickerel Lake, Ainsworth, Langlade County, WI. No known individual was identified.  No associated funerary objects were noted, althrough the find was recorded as ""Historic Indian"", suggesting funerary objects may have been present. The Pine Point site was surveyed and recored as 47Lg21 (LMA 21493W), in conjunction with the 1968 Wild Rivers Project Site Survey, directed by Dr Rover J. Salzer, Beloit College Professor of Anthropology. The owners of the Pine Point Resort donated the recovered remains to the Logan Museum of Anthropology in 1968.",Ojibwa and Menominee,none,"culturally

column1: Bad River Band of the Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa Indians of the Bad River Reservation, Wisconsin,BadRiver,"Wisconsin Historical Society, Museum Division",WiHiSoc,Wisconsin,Ashland,Madeline Island,Catalog #: 7302.1-5 Accession #: 47 As-24 [73302.1-5],1,1,"Excavated by Robert J. Salzer and Robert A. Birmingham in the 1970s. Collection was at the Logan Museum of Anthropology, Beloit College until 1993 when it was supposedly transferred to the WHS Madeline Island Museum. Logan Museum curators found the reamins in 2008 boxed along with unprocessed soil sampls. Logan Museum transferred the reamins to the WHS, who had clear title to all the collections, including these remains.",,"a soil matrix, which includes with it a textile fragment, trade beads, nail fragments, and metal fragments.","published in the FR 8/24/2010 culturally affiliated with the Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa Indians of the Bad River Reservation, Wisconsin, and Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians of Wisconsin."

Ho-Chunk Nation of Wisconsin,HoChunkNation,"Univ. of Wisconsin, Stevens Point",UWStevensPoint,Wisconsin,Portage,Bigelow-Hamilton (47-Pr-29),N/A,2,71,"In the late 1950s, human remains were removed fromm the Bigelow-Hamilton site (47-Pr-29), Portage County, WI, by George Dixon. Mr. Dixon subsequently donated the human remains and associated funerary objects to the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point. No known individuals were identified. Most of the human remains and associated funerary objects were reinterred in 1986 and 1987 at the request of the Wisconsin Winnebago Tribe, now called the Ho-Chunk Nation of Wisconsin. In 1994, 1995, and 2001, additional human remains representing a minimum of two individuals and associated funerary objects from  the Bigelow-Hamilton site were discovered in the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point collections.",,"1 fragment of mink or otter fur, 2 textile fragments, 9 shell fragments, 6 stone tools, 48 stone flakes, 3 Madison Plain sherds, and 2 cord-impressed sherds.",

Ho-Chunk Nation of Wisconsin,HoChunkNation,"Wisconsin Historical Society, Museum Division",WiHiSoc,Wisconsin,Fond du Lac,"Fond du Lac Township, near Luco Creek 47-FD-0242",Catalog #: A8949,1,2,"In 1926, human remains were removed from a grave near Luco Creek during sewer construction. Workers encountered three skeletons with associated funerary objects.",,one trade sheet silver headdress and a fragment of woven cloth,publish in the FR 5/13/2010 culturally affiliated with the Ho-Chunk Nation of Wisconsin and the Winnebago Tribe of Nebraska

",Corrects notice NIC0266 published 3/26/1999 increased MNI fromm 46 to 48 and AFO fromm 38 to 39.

column1: Lac du Flambeau Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians of the Lac du Flambeau Reservation of Wisconsin,LacDuFlambeau,Milwaukee Public Museum,MilwaukeePublicMuseum,Wisconsin,Vilas,"Fox Island, Rest Lake (47-VI-7)",N/A,2,20,"In 1902, human remains representing two individuals and associated funerary objects were remomved during excavation of a mound burial on Fox Island, Rest Lake (47-VIA-7), Manitowosh Waters Township, Vilas County, WI, by James G. Albright. The human remains and some (an unknown number) of the associated funerary objects were sole to the Wisconsin Natural History Society in 1902. The Wisconsin Natural History Society donated the remains and associated funerary objects to the Milwaukee Public Museum the same year. Mr. Albright donated the remaining associated funerary objects to the Milwaukee Public Museum in 1942.",,"A German silver brooch with engraved geometric designs, a broken porcelain saucer, fragments of a metal bucket that originally contained a granulated substance (maple sugar?), half of a tin cup, birch bark wrappings, metal fragments, glass beads, shell, wood fragments, wool cloth fragments, a horn knife handle, a pocket mirror, two German silver bracelets with a piece of silk ribbon, fragments of a metal necklace with imitation gems, spectable glass with copper frame, an iron axe head, a knife with wood handle, a hatchet head, and a limestone Micmac-style pipe.",

Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin,Menominee,Oshkosh Public Museum,NevillePublic,Wisconsin,Marinette,Potato Rapids Burial Site (47-Mt-79),Catalog #: ANNEXS1,1,31,"In 1964, human remains representing 1 individual and 31 associated funerary objects were removed during excavations conducted by the Wisconsin Archaeological Society from the Potato Rapids Burial Site (47-Mt-79), Peshtigo, Marinette County, WI These remains and objects were donated to the Oshkosh Public Museum by the Wisconsin Archaeological Society at an unknown date after 1964.",,"iron axe, two bone beads wampum beads, seed beadwork, a metal bowl, five silver bracelets, four silver brooches, six silver buttons, one metal can, one comb, one silver crescent, two silver earrings, three gunflints, one clay pipe, fabric, and fiber remains",published in FR 10/25/2000 culturally affiliated with the Menominee Indian Tribe of WI

Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin,Menominee,Oshkosh Public Museum,NevillePublic,Wisconsin,Winnebago,Robert Grignon Trading Post Site (47-Wn-137),Catalog #: ANNEXS23B,1,0,"Circa 1936, human remains representing one individual were removed from the Robert Grignon Trading Post Site (47-Wn-137), Winnebago, WI by Oshkosh Public Museum staff Arthur Kannenberg. Documentation indicates that the tombstone that marked this burial identified the remains as those of ""Mary/wife of/Robert Grignon/died Dec 24, 1851/age/37 years"". The remains were, reportedly, re-buried inn the same grave except for two vertebrae and two teeth that are now in the possession of the Oshkosh Public Museum. A contemporaneous accound of the excavation of the grave identified Mary Grignon as the daughter of a full-blodded Menominee chief. Other historical sources indicate that her Menominee name is Wak-nau-go-lak.",,,published in FR 10/25/2000 culturally affiliated with the Menominee Indian Tribe of WI

Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin,Menominee,"U.S. Dept.of Interior, BIA",DeptIntBIA,Wisconsin,Menominee,Menominee Indian Reservation in Keshena,N/A,1,20,"In 1926, Oshkosh Public Museum staff Arthur Kannenberg excavated the graves of two individuals located on the Menominee Indian Reservation in Keshena, WI. The remains of one individual, believed to have been those of Chief Oshkosh, were re-interred at a new location in Oshkosh, WI shortly thereafter. The remains of the second individual, believed to have been those of one of Chief Oshkosh's wives, were not re-located. Two cervical vertebrae were removed from one of the two graves and donated to the Oshkosh Public Museum by an unknown person, presumably Mr. Kannenberg, at an unknown time after 1926. An unknown person, presumably Mr. Kannenberg, retained remnants of Chief Oshkosh's original casket, including pieces of glass, metal, cloth, wood, beads, three nails, and scraps of beaded cloth. These nine funerary objects were donated to the Oshkosh Public Museum, presumably by Mr. Kannenberg, at an unknown time between 1926-1945. At an unknown time, but presumably during the 1926 exhumation, 11 funerary objects consisting of a wooden spool, 8 buttons, shears, and 1 nail were collected from the grave of a wife of Chief Oshkosh. They were donated to the Oshkosh Public Museum by an unknown person, but presumed to be Mr. Kannenberg, at an unknown time between 1926-1945.",,"pieces of glass, metal, cloth, wood, beads, three nails, and scraps of beaded cloth",published inn FR 10/25/2000 culturally affiliated with Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin. Repatriated in 2001

Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin,Menominee,"U.S. Dept. of Interior, BIA",DeptIntBIA,Wisconsin,Shawano,Mound on Menominee Reservation,Catalog #: 1950-6268 Accession #: 1950-6268,1,3,"In 1928, human remains representing a minimum of one individual were removed from a mound located within the boundaries of the Menominee Indian Tribe Reservation, Menominee County (formerly Shawano County), WI, by Arthur P. Kannenberg and John V. Satterlee. The exact location is not known. In 1950, the museum obtained the human remains, associated funerary objects, and unassociated funerary objects from the wife of Arthur P. Kannenberg",Menominee,earrings,published in the Federal Register 07/20/2010 culturally affiliated with the Pawnee Nation of Oklahoma. Repatriated February 2016 to the Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin

Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin,Menominee,"Univ. of Wisconsin, Stevens Point",UWStevensPoint,Wisconsin,Portage,Bigelow-Hamilton (47-Pr-29),N/A,2,71,"In the late 1950s, human remains were removed fromm the Bigelow-Hamilton site (47-Pr-29), Portage County, WI, by George Dixon. Mr. Dixon subsequently donated the human remains and associated funerary objects to the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point. No known individuals were identified. Most of the human remains and associated funerary objects were reinterred in 1986 and 1987 at the request of the Wisconsin Winnebago Tribe, now called the Ho-Chunk Nation of Wisconsin. In 1994, 1995, and 2001, additional human remains representing a minimum of two individuals and associated funerary objects from  the Bigelow-Hamilton site were discovered in the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point collections.",,"1 fragment of mink or otter  fur, 2 textile fragments, 9 shell fragments, 6 stone tools, 48 stone flakes, 3 Madison Plain sherds, and 2 cord-impressed sherds",

column1: Forest County Potawatomi Community of Wisconsin Potawatomi Indians, Wisconsin,ForestCountyPotawatomi,"Wisconsin Historical Society, Museum Division",WiHiSoc,Wisconsin,Taylor,Indian Farms [47-Ta-0018],Catalog #: F2005.4 Accession #: 47 Ta-18,1,0,"In 1966, human remains representing a minimum of one individual were removed fromm Indian Farms [47-Ta-0018], in Taylor County, WI. On July 17, 1966, archeologists from the Wisconsin Historical Society visited Indian Farms to investigate a report of recent looting. The archeologist contact local law enforcement and recovered the fragementary remains of a child found on the ground surface. The fragmentary remains were brought back to the Wisconsin Historical Society.",Potawatomi or Ojibwe,"Culturally affiliated with the Forest County Potawatomi Community, Wisconsin",

Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians of Wisconsin,RedCliff,"Beloit College, Logan Museum of Anthropology",BeloitLoganMuseumOfAnthropology,Wisconsin,Ashland,Marina site (47As24),LMA 7302,2,9,"In 1975 human remains representing a minimum of one individual (""Burial 2"") were removed from the Marina site (47As24), La Pointe Township, Madeline Island, Ashland County, WI by crews from Beloit College directed by Robert J. Salzer under the terms of an agreement between Beloit College and the Interagency Archeological Services branch of the National Park Service. In 1977, workers installing a sewer line removed the remains of another individual from the site (""Burial 12""), along with nine associated copper bracelets.",Lake Superior Ojibwa,copper bracelets,"culturally affiliated with the Bad River Band of Lake Superior Indians of the Bad River Reservation, Wisconsin

column1: Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians of Wisconsin,RedCliff,"Beloit College, Logan Museum of Anthropology",BeloitLoganMuseumOfAnthropology,Wisconsin,Langlade,Pine Point site(47Lg21),LMA 21493W,1,0,"In 1968 or earlier, human remains representing a single individual were recovered during installation of a septic tank with a backhoe at the Pine Point Resort, Pickerel Lake, Ainsworth, Langlade County, WI. No known individual was identified.  No associated funerary objects were noted, althrough the find was recorded as ""Historic Indian"", suggesting funerary objects may have been present. The Pine Point site was surveyed and recored as 47Lg21 (LMA 21493W), in conjunction with the 1968 Wild Rivers Project Site Survey, directed by Dr Rover J. Salzer, Beloit College Professor of Anthropology. The owners of the Pine Point Resort donated the recovered remains to the Logan Museum of Anthropology in 1968.",Ojibwa and Menominee,none,"culturally affiliated with the Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa Indians of the Bad River Reservation, Wisconsin
